radiology_notes.text:
UPPER ARM VENOUS MAPPING

CLINICAL INFORMATION:  History of multiple failed AV fistula grafts seen both
upper extremities.

Examination of the right upper extremity reveals the cephalic vein to be
patent.  This is quite small measuring 1.4-1.8 mm in the forearm, 2.5-2.7 mm
at the level of the elbow and 1.5-4.2 mm in the upper arm, towards the
shoulder.  The basilic vein on this side is also quite small below the elbow
measuring between 1.4 and 1.8 mm, 2.4 mm above the elbow and 2.9 mm towards
the axilla.  Brachial artery is visualized and is reportedly duplicated. 
Unclear whether this is real or just represents high takeoff of the radial
artery.
Left upper extremity:
Cephalic vein is patent and measures 0.9-1 mm in the forearm, 1.7 at the level
of the elbow and 1.7-3.3 towards the shoulder.  The basilic vein is visualized
from the elbow proximally measuring 2.3-2.5 mm at the level of the elbow and
2.7-3.1 mm in the upper arm.  The brachial artery is patent and the radial
artery calcified. Central catheter overlying the left shoulder.

HISTORY:  HIV with dyspnea.

FINDINGS:  In comparison with the study of ___, there is no interval change
or evidence of acute cardiopulmonary disease.  No pneumonia, vascular
congestion, or pleural effusion.  

Dialysis catheter from an inferior approach again extends to the right atrium.

HISTORY:  Aching and left shoulder pain.

TECHNIQUE:  Left shoulder, 3 views.

COMPARISON:  Comparison is made to chest radiographs from ___ and ___.  This study is read in conjunction with
CT of the chest from ___.

FINDINGS:

There is no fracture, dislocation or degenerative change involving the
glenohumeral or AC joint.  No focal lytic or sclerotic lesion is identified. 
No soft tissue calcification is noted.  Within the left axilla, there is
evidence of prior vascular graft surgery, seen previously on prior chest
radiographs and chest CT, unchanged.

IMPRESSION:

No evidence of fracture or dislocation.

HISTORY:  ___ female with nausea, rule out pneumonia. 

COMPARISON :

Prior exam from ___.  

FINDINGS:

Portable AP upright chest radiograph was provided.  Surgical clips are again
noted in the right axilla.  A dialysis catheter extending from the IVC into
the right atrium is also again noted.  Heart size is within normal limits. 
The mediastinal contour is stable.  There is no focal consolidation, effusion
or pneumothorax.  While there is no overt edema or definite signs for fluid
overload, mild hilar congestion is noted.  Bony structures are intact.  A
vascular stent is partially imaged in the left axilla.  

IMPRESSION:

Possible mild hilar congestion.  Otherwise unremarkable.

INDICATION:   Sudden onset headache.  Assess for intracranial hemorrhage.

COMPARISONS:  CT head of ___ and MR head dated ___.

TECHNIQUE:  MDCT acquired contiguous images through the head were obtained
without intravenous contrast at 5 mm slice thickness.  Coronally and
sagittally reformatted images are provided.  

FINDINGS:  There is no evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage, mass effect
or shift of normally midline structures.  There is no cerebral edema or loss
of gray-white matter differentiation to suggest an acute ischemic event.  The
sulci and ventricles are prominent, likely age-related involutional changes. 
Coarse calcifications along the falx and tentorium cerebelli are unchanged. 
The orbits are unremarkable.  No acute fracture.  Imaged paranasal sinuses and
mastoid air cells are clear. Increased sclerosis and slight permeative
appearance of the osseous structures, more conspicuous since prior, likely
relates to renal osteodystrophy.

IMPRESSION: No acute intracranial process.

INDICATION:  History of AFib with RVR.  Please evaluate for pneumonia or CHF.

COMPARISONS:  Chest radiographs dated back to ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Frontal and lateral radiographs of the chest.

FINDINGS:  Surgical clips are again seen along the right axilla.  A dialysis
catheter extends from the IVC into the right atrium.  The heart size is within
normal limits.  No focal consolidation concerning for pneumonia is identified.
There is no large pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  The visualized osseous
structures are unremarkable.

IMPRESSION:  

No acute intrathoracic abnormalities identified.

INDICATION:  HIV, AFib, on Coumadin, here with worsening headache.  Evaluate
for mass.

COMPARISON:  Comparison is made to head CT performed ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Non-contrast axial images obtained through the brain.  Coronal and
sagittal reformations are provided.

RADIATION DOSE:  892 mGy-cm.

FINDINGS:  There is no evidence of hemorrhage, edema, large masses, mass
effect or acute infarct.  Ventricles and sulci are normal in size and
configuration.  Dense calcifications of the falx and tentorium cerebelli as
well as mottled appearance of the osseous structures likely reflect known
renal dystrophy.  The mastoid air cells and middle ear cavities are clear. 
Minimal mucosal thickening present within the right maxillary sinus.  Orbits
are unremarkable.  No soft tissue swelling identified.

IMPRESSION:  No acute intracranial process.  If continued concern for mass, it
could be further evaluated with MRI.

EXAMINATION:  CT ABD AND PELVIS WITH CONTRAST

INDICATION:  Abominal pain

TECHNIQUE:  MDCT axial images were acquired through abdomen and pelvis
following intravenous administration of 130cc of Omnipaque. Coronal and
sagittal reformations were performed.

DOSE:  DLP: 377 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  CTA abdomen and pelvis dated ___

FINDINGS: 

CHEST:

There is bibasilar atelectasis.  There is calcification of the mitral annulus.
No pleural or pericardial effusion.  A right femoral central line ends in the
right atrium.

ABDOMEN:

The liver enhances homogeneously without focal lesion or intrahepatic biliary
dilatation. The gallbladder is unremarkable and the portal vein is patent. The
pancreas and adrenal glands are unremarkable.  Multiple splenic hemangiomas
are again noted. The kidneys are atrophic with innumerable bilateral renal
cysts compatible with dialysis related renal cystic disease. Some of the cysts
are intermediate density likely representing hemorrhagic cysts. Nonobstructing
stones are seen the lower pole right renal collecting system

The small and large bowel are normal in caliber without evidence of
obstruction.  There is a moderate amount of stool within the colon.  There is
no retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy by CT size criteria. No
ascites, free air or abdominal hernia.  A vascular stent is seen in the IVC.

PELVIS:

The urinary bladder is collapsed.  There is no evidence of pelvic or inguinal
lymphadenopathy.  There is no free fluid in the pelvis. Uterus and adnexa are
unremarkable.

BONES AND SOFT TISSUES:

No lytic or sclerotic lesion suspicious for malignancy is present.  Diffuse
sclerosis of the osseous structures is compatible with renal osteodystrophy.

IMPRESSION:



1. No acute intra-abdominal process to explain patient's symptoms.
2. Unchanged atrophic kidneys with numerous bilateral cysts compatible with
dialysis related renal cystic disease
3. Unchanged vascular stent in the IVC

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with advanced AIDS, ESRD on HD, h/o distal
ischemic dz/calciphylaxis s/p b/l toe gangrene s/p b/l TMA, now with new L
third finger necrosis for several months, possibly anticipating
amputation,vascular surgery requesting CTA chest and upper ext in anticipation
of possible endovascular procedure  // assess for large central vessel
obstruction in pt with new L third finger necrosis

TECHNIQUE:  Axial multidetector CT images were obtained through the thorax
after the uneventful administration of 100 cc of Omnipaque intravenous
contrast.
Reformatted coronal, sagittal, thin slice axial images, and oblique maximal
intensity projection images were submitted to PACS and reviewed.

DOSE:  DLP:  Total DLP (Body) = 142 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  CT chest ___

FINDINGS: 

There is significant calcification and significant occlusion of the left
brachiocephalic vein, left subclavian vein, right subclavian vein and right
brachiocephalic vein, best appreciated on coronal  view (08:47-54).  These
calcifications are more significant as compared to CT chest ___. 
Evaluation of the jugular veins bilaterally is limited.  The superior vena
cava is patent and opacified and a dilated azygos vein is seen draining into
this SVC (05:40).  There is no evidence of collateral flow across the
bilateral brachiocephalic veins.

The aorta and its major branch vessels are patent, with no evidence of
stenosis, occlusion, dissection, or aneurysmal formation.  There is mild
calcification of the ascending aorta, aortic arch, and descending aorta.  The
left subclavian artery is patent to the axilla.  There is no evidence of
penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer or aortic arch atheroma present. There are
apparently abandoned vascular grafts in the bilateral axilla.

The pulmonary arteries are well opacified to the subsegmental level, with no
evidence of filling defect within the main, right, left, lobar, segmental or
subsegmental pulmonary arteries.  The main and right pulmonary arteries are
normal in caliber, and there is no evidence of right heart strain.

Mild dependent atelectasis is seen bilaterally.  There are mild ground-glass
changes in the dependent regions of the bilateral lung bases, most prominent
in the left lower lobe (6:166).  This most likely represents atelectasis.
There is no sign of pulmonary edema.  The airways are patent to the
subsegmental level.

No supraclavicular, axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.  The
thyroid gland appears unremarkable.

No significant pericardial or pleural effusion.

Limited images of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.

No lytic or blastic osseous lesion suspicious for malignancy is identified.


IMPRESSION: 

1.  Thoracic aorta is patent with mild atherosclerosis and no significant
stenosis or acute aortic abnormality.  Left subclavian artery is patent to the
axilla without concerning finding.
2.  Chronic occlusion of the left and right brachiocephalic veins and right
subclavian veins.  The superior vena cava is patent with a distended azygos
vein providing flow from intercostal veins.  The status of the jugular veins
and left subclavian vein is uncertain on this predominantly arterial study.
3.  Ground-glass opacities in the dependent areas of the bilateral lung bases
which most likely represent atelectasis superimposed on mild chronic
abnormalities.  No evidence of pulmonary edema.

INDICATION:  ___ with cough  // evidence of pneumonia

TECHNIQUE:  Single AP view of the chest.

COMPARISON:  ___.

FINDINGS: 

Central venous catheter projects from the inferior field of view with tip in
the right atrium.  The lungs are clear.  The cardiomediastinal silhouette is
within normal limits.  Aortic nipple is incidentally noted.  No acute osseous
abnormalities.  Left upper extremity graft is noted as well as right upper
extremity vascular calcifications versus graft.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute cardiopulmonary process.

EXAMINATION:  PELVIS, NON-OBSTETRIC

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with h/o fibroids s/p remote ablation now with
2 months of frequent heavy menses lasting 10d with many clots, every 2wks,
evaluate for fibroids, mass, endometrial thickening

TECHNIQUE:  Grayscale ultrasound images of the pelvis were obtained with
transabdominal approach followed by transvaginal approach for further
delineation of uterine and ovarian anatomy.

COMPARISON:  CT of the abdomen pelvis dated ___

FINDINGS: 

Technically limited study with poor visualization of the pelvic structures due
to limited sonographic windows.  Please note that on prior CT the uteris is
retroflexed and retroverted which likely explains the technical difficulty.

IMPRESSION: 

Nondiagnostic study due to poor sonographic windows.  MRI of without contrast
could be considered for further anatomic characterization, if clinically
indicated.

EXAMINATION:  CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST

INDICATION:  ___ woman with altered mental status.  Evaluate for acute
process.

TECHNIQUE:  Contiguous axial images of the brain were obtained without
contrast. Coronal and sagittal reformations as well as bone algorithm
reconstructions were provided and reviewed.

DOSE:  Acquisition sequence:
   1) Sequenced Acquisition 16.0 s, 16.0 cm; CTDIvol = 50.2 mGy (Head) DLP =
802.7 mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Head) = 803 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  PET-CT of ___.

FINDINGS: 

There is no evidence of infarction, hemorrhage, edema, or mass.  The
ventricles and sulci are normal in size and configuration.  Prominent
calcification along the falx and tentorium is unchanged since the prior head
CT.

There is no evidence of fracture.  Re- demonstration of a mottled appearance
of the calvarium, likely reflecting known renal osteodystrophy.  The
visualized portion of the paranasal sinuses, mastoid air cells, and middle ear
cavities are clear.  The visualized portion of the orbits are unremarkable.

IMPRESSION: 

1.  No acute intracranial process.  Specifically, no acute intracranial
hemorrhage.

2.  Unchanged prominent calcifications along the falx and tentorium and
mottled appearance of the calvarium, likely reflecting known renal
osteodystrophy.  Findings are similar to that of ___.

EXAMINATION:   CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  History: ___ with weakness, confusion at dialysis today. 
Evaluate for acute process.

TECHNIQUE:  Single portable AP view of the chest.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph ___.

FINDINGS: 

Compared with the prior radiograph, no significant interval change. The
central venous catheter projects from the inferior field of view with tip in
the right atrium.  Lungs are clear without focal consolidation, pleural
effusion, or pneumothorax.  Incidentally noted aortic nipple is unchanged. 
Left upper extremity graft is partially visualized, along with right upper
extremity densely calcified graft or vascular calcifications.

IMPRESSION: 

No new focal consolidation concerning for pneumonia.  No significant change
since ___.

EXAMINATION:  ART EXT (REST ONLY)

CLINICAL HISTORY  ___ year old woman with s/p Right Angiogram  // Eval patency
of gram      Eval patency of gram

FINDINGS: 

Doppler waveform analysis reveals monophasic waveforms at the DP bilaterally. 
Ankle brachial indices could not be obtained due to noncompressible vessels. 
Pulse volume recordings demonstrate mild dampening at the ankle level while
bilaterally with further dampening at the right metatarsal.

IMPRESSION:


Noncompressible vessels with moderate dampening of PVRs bilaterally.

EXAMINATION:  ART DUP EXT LO UNI;F/U

CLINICAL HISTORY  ___ year old woman with s/p Right Angiogram  // EVAL patency
of Stent      EVAL patency of Stent

FINDINGS: 

Duplex was performed of the right lower extremity arterial system.  The study
is technically limited as the patient could not move the leg and there is
substantial swelling.  Common femoral and superficial femoral arteries are
patent with normal velocities.  The anterior tibial in the distal calf and
ankle are patent with normal velocities.  The intervening segment could not be
interrogated.  Waveforms are monophasic throughout the visualized segments.

IMPRESSION:


Limited study with patent common femoral superficial femoral and distal
anterior tibial arteries.

INDICATION:  ___ with throbbing L knee pain after her leg was forcibly lifted
by RN at her facility.

COMPARISON:  No priors

FINDINGS: 

AP, oblique and lateral views of the left knee were provided.  Diffuse
demineralization noted with extensive soft tissue and vascular calcification. 
No definite fracture or dislocation.  No joint effusion is seen.

IMPRESSION: 

As above.

EXAMINATION:  BILATERAL DIGITAL DIAGNOSTIC MAMMOGRAM INTERPRETED WITH CAD AND
BILATERAL BREAST ULTRASOUND

INDICATION:  ___ woman with bilateral breast lumps.  Family history of
ovarian cancer.  History of HIV/AIDS and end stage renal disease on
hemodialysis.

COMPARISON:  No prior study was available at the time of this interpretation.

TECHNIQUE:  CC and MLO and a lateral and spot compression views were obtained.
Positioning is limited due to patient in wheelchair with 1 leg.  Metallic BBs
placed in the bilateral breast areas of clinical concern as directed by the
patient.  Computer aided detection was utilized and assisted with
interpretation.  Targeted ultrasound was performed with patient sitting in
wheelchair as she recently had leg amputation and requires mechanical lift to
stretcher, which was not available.

FINDINGS: 

Tissue density: C- The breast tissue is heterogeneously dense which may
obscure detection of small masses.
Underlying the metallic BB in the right breast, there are 2 adjacent masses, 1
reniform and 1 oval with circumscribed margins.  There is an asymmetry
underlying the left breast metallic BB on the craniocaudal spot compression
view.  Otherwise, there is no suspicious mass, unexplained architectural
distortion or suspicious grouped microcalcification in either breast.  There
is diffuse vascular calcification in both breasts.

BREAST ULTRASOUND:  Targeted ultrasound was performed as directed by the
patient.  In the left breast at the 9 o'clock position 4 cm from the nipple,
corresponding to the mammographic asymmetry, there is an oval, hypo a coexist
mass with almost tubular configuration and peripheral hyperechogenicity,
measuring approximately 1.0 x 01.5 x 0.5 cm.  There is a similar appearing
smaller adjacent mass measuring 0.5 x 0.8 x 0.4 cm.

Targeted ultrasound of the right breast was performed as directed by the
patient.  In the right breast from the 7 o'clock through the 9 o'clock
positions, there is no suspicious solid or cystic mass.  At the 10 o'clock
position of the right breast 4 cm from the nipple, corresponding to the
mammographic masses, there are 2 adjacent hypoechoic oval masses with
peripheral hyperechogenicity, similar in appearance to the masses in the left
breast.  The dominant mass measures 1.7 x 1.5 x 0.8 cm and the smaller mass
measures 1.1 x 0.9 x 0.5 cm.  In addition, there is a third similar appearing
smaller mass measuring approximately 0.9 x 1.2 x 0.4 cm.

IMPRESSION: 

Bilateral similar appearing breast masses are suspicious.  There is no
reported history of trauma or superficial bruising, which is not identified
during imaging.  The patient reports receiving heparin during hemodialysis,
raising the possibility of evolving hematomas.  However, given similar
appearance of bilateral breast masses, patient comorbidities and limited
mobility, including HIV/AIDS, biopsy of at least the dominant mass in the
right breast is recommended to exclude other etiologies, including breast
carcinoma, lymphoma or HIV related malignancy.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  Ultrasound-guided core biopsy of dominant right breast
mass.

NOTIFICATION:  Findings and recommendation for biopsy were reviewed with the
patient who agrees with this plan. She was given information to schedule her
biopsy with availability of stretcher or lift given patient mobility
limitations.She subsequently scheduled the biopsy with stretcher availability
for ___.  Findings recommendations were transmitted by the critical
results communication system to Dr. ___ at approximately 14:35 ___.

BI-RADS:  4B Suspicious - moderate suspicion for 
malignancy.

EXAMINATION:  BILATERAL BREAST ULTRASOUND

INDICATION:  ___ woman with multiple medical comorbidities presents
for ultrasound-guided core biopsy of right breast mass at 10 o'clock, 4 cm the
nipple.  However, the patient elected to cancel the biopsy and undergo imaging
follow-up today.

COMPARISON:  Mammogram and ultrasound dated ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Targeted breast ultrasound was performed.  Selected images were
obtained.

FINDINGS: 

RIGHT BREAST: At 10 o'clock, 4 cm from the nipple again seen is an oval,
tubular hypoechoic mass with peripheral hyperechogenicity, which measures
approximately 1.3 x 0.7 x 0.4 cm, previously 1.7 x 1.5 x 0.8 cm.  A slightly
smaller, similar appearing mass is also seen at 10 o'clock, 4 cm from the
nipple, measuring 1.1 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm, previously 0.9 x 1.2 x 0.4 cm.  Overall,
allowing for differences in measurement technique, these areas appear grossly
stable.

LEFT BREAST: At 9 o'clock, 4 cm from the nipple there is a oval, tubular
hypoechoic mass with peripheral hyperechogenicity, which measures
approximately 0.8 x 0.4 x 1.4 cm, previously 1 x 0.5 x 1.5 cm.  Overall,
allowing for differences in measurement technique, this area appears grossly
stable.

IMPRESSION:


1. No significant interval change of the bilateral similar appearing breast
masses, as compared to ___.  Rather than undergo biopsy at this time,
the patient has elected for imaging follow-up in 6 months time.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  Six-month follow-up bilateral breast ultrasound.

NOTIFICATION:  Findings and recommendation were reviewed with the patient who
agrees with the plan.  Follow-up imaging in 6 months was scheduled prior to
her leaving the department.

BI-RADS:  3 Probably Benign.

EXAMINATION:  LIVER OR GALLBLADDER US (SINGLE ORGAN)

INDICATION:  ___ with RUQ tenderness, pos blood cultures// ?cholecystitis

TECHNIQUE:  Grey scale and color Doppler ultrasound images of the abdomen were
obtained.

COMPARISON:  CT abdomen pelvis from ___.  Right upper quadrant
ultrasound from ___.

FINDINGS: 

LIVER: The hepatic parenchyma appears within normal limits. The contour of the
liver is smooth. There is no focal liver mass. The main portal vein is patent
with hepatopetal flow. There is no ascites.  A 1.8 x 0.4 cm hypoechoic
structure seen anterior to the pancreas appears to correspond to a caval lymph
node seen on prior CT abdomen pelvis from ___.

BILE DUCTS: There is no intrahepatic biliary dilation. The CHD measures 2 mm.

GALLBLADDER: There is no evidence of stones or gallbladder wall thickening.  A
gallbladder fold is noted.

PANCREAS: The imaged portion of the pancreas appears within normal limits,
without masses or pancreatic ductal dilation, with portions of the pancreatic
tail obscured by overlying bowel gas.

SPLEEN:  Normal echogenicity, measuring 10.4 cm.

KIDNEYS:  Limited views of the right kidney show no hydronephrosis.

RETROPERITONEUM:  The visualized portions of aorta and IVC are within normal
limits.

IMPRESSION: 

No cholelithiasis or evidence of cholecystitis.

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with HIV (CD ___, ESRD on HD MWF,
history of calciphylaxis with warfarin and severe PVD s/p right BKA and left
toe amputations, and chronic hypotension (SBPs ___ with mentation) who
admitted ___ with sepsis, found to have a ruptured right renal cyst and
proteus mirabilis bacteremia.// evaluate right renal cyst s/p rupture with
residual rim enhancing area

TECHNIQUE:   Single phase split bolus contrast: MDCT axial images were
acquired through the abdomen and pelvis following intravenous contrast
administration with split bolus technique.
Oral contrast was administered.
Coronal and sagittal reformations were performed and reviewed on PACS.

DOSE:  Acquisition sequence:
   1) Spiral Acquisition 8.1 s, 52.9 cm; CTDIvol = 12.3 mGy (Body) DLP = 640.7
mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Body) = 641 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  ___

FINDINGS: 

LOWER CHEST: There is improved bibasilar airspace disease.

ABDOMEN: The unenhanced liver, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas and adrenal
glands are unremarkable.
No biliary ductal dilatation demonstrated.

URINARY: The kidneys are again noted to be markedly atrophic.  There are
bilateral hypodense lesions some of which are too small to characterize while
others are cysts.  There are multiple mildly hyperdense lesions some with a
hyperdense rim, all of which remain indeterminate.  The previously drained
right hyperdense cyst measures 2.7 cm, previously 3.4 cm.  The drain has been
removed.  Please note that residual enhancement questionned on history is not
assessed due to the lack of intravenous contrast medium, however, the
surrounding soft tissue stranding seen prior to drainage is no longer
visualized.

GASTROINTESTINAL: No intestinal obstruction or ascites.  The appendix is
unremarkable.

PELVIS: There is no free fluid in the pelvis.  The uterus and adnexa are
within normal limits for age .

LYMPH NODES: No enlarged abdominal or pelvic lymph nodes.  IVC stent and left
central femoral catheter ending in the right atrium is again noted.

VASCULAR: Extensive vascular calcifications are again demonstrated.  No
retroperitoneal hematoma visualized.

BONES: No aggressive osseous lesions.

IMPRESSION:


1. Interval decrease of right renal cyst which previously demonstrated a
drain.  The residual enhancement questionned in the history is not assessed
due to the lack of intravenous contrast medium, however, there are improved
surrounding inflammatory changes.
2. No retroperitoneal hematoma visualized.
3. Improvement of bibasilar airspace disease.

EXAMINATION:  CT abdomen pelvis with contrast

INDICATION:  NO_PO contrast; History: ___ with known c diff, recurrent renal
abscess and abdominal painNO_PO contrast// etiology of pain

TECHNIQUE:   Single phase split bolus contrast: MDCT axial images were
acquired through the abdomen and pelvis following intravenous contrast
administration with split bolus technique.
Oral contrast was administered.
Coronal and sagittal reformations were performed and reviewed on PACS.

DOSE:  Acquisition sequence:
   1) Spiral Acquisition 6.7 s, 52.6 cm; CTDIvol = 13.5 mGy (Body) DLP = 707.8
mGy-cm.
 Total DLP (Body) = 708 mGy-cm.

COMPARISON:  CT from ___.

FINDINGS: 

LOWER CHEST: Visualized lung fields are within normal limits. There is no
evidence of pleural or pericardial effusion.  Left femoral line extending to
the level of the right atrium is unchanged from prior exam.  There is subtle
hypodensity in the right atrium/proximal IVC around the tip of catheter, not
substantially changed from prior exam (2:6) and extends from the chronic
occlusion of the right hepatic vein.

ABDOMEN:

HEPATOBILIARY: There are geographic areas of enhancement, likely reflecting
perfusional anomaly secondary to the chronic occlusion of the right hepatic
vein.  There is no evidence of focal lesions.  There is no evidence of
intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary dilatation.  The gallbladder is within
normal limits.

PANCREAS: The pancreas has normal attenuation throughout, without evidence of
focal lesions or pancreatic ductal dilatation.  There is no peripancreatic
stranding.

SPLEEN: Multiple splenic hypodensities are unchanged from prior exam and
thought to represent splenic infarcts.

ADRENALS: The right and left adrenal glands are normal in size and shape.

URINARY: The kidneys are chronically atrophic with innumerable cysts/fluid
collections, some hemorrhagic.  The posterior left interpolar region fluid
collections has decreased in size since ___, now measuring 1.1 x
1.3 cm, previously 2.7 x 2.6 cm.  There is no evidence of focal renal lesions
or hydronephrosis.  There is no perinephric abnormality.

GASTROINTESTINAL: The stomach is unremarkable.  Small bowel loops demonstrate
normal caliber, wall thickness, and enhancement throughout.  The colon and
rectum are within normal limits.  The appendix is normal (02:54).

PELVIS: The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable.  There is no
free fluid in the pelvis.

REPRODUCTIVE ORGANS: The uterus and bilateral adnexae are within normal
limits.

LYMPH NODES: There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy.  There
is no pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy.

VASCULAR: There is no abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Moderate atherosclerotic
disease is noted.  IVC filter with a left femoral line is stable in
positioning.

BONES: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or acute fracture. 
Bones are diffusely demineralized.

SOFT TISSUES: The abdominal and pelvic wall is within normal limits.

IMPRESSION:


1. Thrombus around the tip of the femoral catheter at the IVC extending from
the chronic occlusion of the right hepatic vein, unchanged from prior exam.
2. Interval decrease in the size of left interpolar region hypodensity, status
post drainage.  Atrophied kidneys.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with known c diff, recurrent renal abscess and
abdominal pain// etiology of pain

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  And chest radiograph from ___.  CT from ___

FINDINGS: 

Aside from mild bibasilar atelectasis, the lungs are grossly clear. There is
catheter projecting over the right atrium, originating from the left femoral
vein, partially imaged.  The IVC filter is also partially imaged.  No pleural
effusion or pneumothorax is seen. Heart size is normal.  Long-standing, severe
venous engorgement of the posterior circulation is responsible for chronic
mediastinal widening.

IMPRESSION: 

No focal consolidation or pleural effusion.

INDICATION:  History: ___ with chest/abd pain// eval for structural process

TECHNIQUE:  Supine left lateral decubitus images of the abdomen were obtained.

COMPARISON:  ___

FINDINGS: 

There is a nonobstructive bowel gas pattern.  No large air-fluid levels are
seen.  There is no evidence of free air.  A catheter is again seen overlying
the abdomen.

IMPRESSION: 

Non-obstructive bowel gas pattern.  No evidence of free air.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with chest/abd pain// eval for structural process

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  ___

FINDINGS: 

Left lower lung platelet atelectasis is re-demonstrated.  No new focal
consolidation is seen.  There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  Cardiac
mediastinal silhouettes are stable.

IMPRESSION: 

No significant change from ___, 1 day prior.

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with ESRD undergoing hemodialysis MWF, now
presenting with an exposed LCF dialysis catheter cuff// replace over wire

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph on ___

TECHNIQUE:  OPERATORS: Dr. ___, Interventional Radiology Fellow and Dr.
___ radiologist performed the procedure. Dr. ___
supervised the trainee during the key components of the procedure and has
reviewed and agrees with the trainee's findings.
ANESTHESIA: 1% lidocaine was injected in the skin and subcutaneous tissues
overlying the access site.
MEDICATIONS: Lidocaine
CONTRAST: 0 ml of Optiray contrast.
FLUOROSCOPY TIME AND DOSE: 4 min, 12 mGy

PROCEDURE:  PROCEDURE DETAILS:

Following the explanation of the risks, benefits and alternatives to the
procedure, written informed consent was obtained from the patient. The patient
was then brought to the angiography suite and placed supine on the exam table.
A pre-procedure time-out was performed per ___ protocol. The left groin was
prepped and draped in the usual sterile fashion.

Under fluoroscopic guidance, an Amplatz wire was passed through the existing
left common femoral vein tunneled dialysis catheter into the superior vena
cava.  The existing tunneled catheter was removed over the wire.  At this
time, a new, 50 cm tunneled hemodialysis catheter was advanced over the wire
into appropriate position with its tip terminating within the right atrium. 
The wire and inner stiffener were removed.  Both lumens of the dialysis
catheter were flushed and aspirated successfully.  The catheter was sutured in
place with 0 silk sutures.  A final spot fluoroscopic image demonstrates good
alignment of the catheter.  The tip is in the right atrium. The catheter was
flushed and both lumens were capped. Sterile dressings were applied. The
patient tolerated the procedure well.

FINDINGS: 

Final fluoroscopic image showing a left common femoral vein approach, tunneled
hemodialysis catheter with tip terminating in the right atrium.

IMPRESSION: 

Successful placement of a 50 cm tip to cuff length tunneled dialysis line. The
tip of the catheter terminates in the right atrium. The catheter is ready for
use.

Left hand: No fracture or dislocation is seen. There are no significant

erosion or periostitis is identified. No suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesion
